text: I think the thing September's
violence the image of the towers coming
down was certainly the most violent
thing I'd ever seen almost unprocess of
bull you know it's sort of unimaginable
unreal what I tried to do to make sense
of it was to think of violence in very
personal terms very intimate terms
because really that was my only
experience of violence and I couldn't
make sense of this huge political event
but I could think about myself my
history people i knew i remember when
abu ghraib happened and i think that was
really the inspiration for dying City
the intersection of sex and violence in
American culture is something that I can
talk about very intimate personal terms
but that really does have relevance now
with the scandal at horror of Abu Ghraib
on a broader larger scale I wouldn't
expect politicians to help us process
deep trauma I wouldn't expect movies and
TV really to do it the the potential for
the deepest exploration of this stuff is
through the less popular arts where
there's less profit to be made there's
more freedom I've certainly felt that
freedom and I think what i can do is go
to the deepest part of myself represent
it try to make sense of it and hope that
my trying to make sense of what confuses
and challenges and upsets me will allow
someone else to to do the same you know
i hope that honesty awakens honesty in
others and that's really when I'm
banking on as an artist on the morning
of 911 I was actually at my writing-desk
I live on the Lower East Side on the
sixth floor of a building that behind me
is a school in a park so that's really
just a single storey building and open
space and I always had a beautiful
perfect view of the world trade center
actually did see the first plane go into
the building and you know it was a
shocking thing to see my father I called
him he was dying at the time or he had
leukemia he died four or five months
later I spoke to him and tried to make
sense of what was happening and I
remembered the the whole the black hole
getting bigger and bigger as the fire
was eating away at the building think
that's
like my father's bodies what's happening
inside of him something's eating away at
him so I saw it in personal terms in a
certain sense from the beginning once I
saw I saw the second plane go in at you
on TV I watched it on TV and then turn
my hand and saw the the fireball finish
but my naked eye at that point although
I had recognized something horrible had
happened I think at that point I went
into denial I had an appointment in
midtown and I actually got on the subway
to go about my day it was sort of Midway
on my journey that I thought what did
you just do you knew something horrible
was happening why did you get on the
subway that period of denial remains
very frightening to me that I that I've
15 or 20 minutes I seem to be able to
disavow what I've seen we process
everything through our own histories or
traumas our intimate lives our past you
know whatever we might decide
intellectually about political issue the
thing I think we can never fully know is
the mystery of ourselves 911 has come to
represent something about myself inside
of me that I'm still trying to come to
terms with and I imagine through the
rest of my life as both a person and an
artist I will be attempting to come to
terms with
